subject: Re: [junit] now it is almost working....
msgSnippet: The test class can t compile because it can t see class X. Check your import statements vs. package structure. -- Stephen Smith, MEng (Wales).
messageBody:
The test class can't compile because it can't see class X. Check your
import statements vs. package structure.
--
Stephen Smith, MEng (Wales).
http://www.stephen-smith.co.uk/

Magnus wrote:
> Hello,
>
> Now I have two classes developed with help from Lasse.
>
>
>
> package example.junit4;
>
> import org.junit.Test;
> import static org.junit.Assert.assertEquals;
> import junit.framework.JUnit4TestAdapter;
>
> public class TestX{
> @Test
> public void numbersAboveOneShouldGetDoubled() throws
> Exception {
> assertEquals(4, new X().met(2));
> assertEquals(6, new X().met(3));
> assertEquals(8, new X().met(4));
> }
>
> @Test
> public void numbersEqualOrBelowOneShouldYield666() throws
> Exception {
> assertEquals(666, new X().met(1));
> assertEquals(666, new X().met(0));
> assertEquals(666, new X().met(-4));
> }
>
> // public static junit.framework.Test suite(){
> // return new JUnit4TestAdapter(LibraryTest.class);
> //}
> }
>
>
>
>
> and:
>
>
> /import java.lang.annotation.Annotation;
> //import junit.framework.Test;
> //import junit.framework.TestCase;
> //import junit.framework.TestSuite;
> //import static org.junit.Assert.*;
> //import org.junit.*;
> //import java.util.*;
>
> public class X{
> public int met (int number) {
> int num = number;
> if (num <= 1)
> return num*2;
> else{
> return 666;
> }
> }
> }
>
>
>
>
> I get 6 errors all with the same problem, namely this:
>
>
> TestX.java:13: connot find symbol
> symbol : class X
> location: class example.junit4.TestX
> assertEquals(8, new X().met()4));
>
>
> It cant find the class? class X exsists and compiles and looks like
> above.
>
> hmm, what is the problem here do you think?
>
>
> Magnus
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>

>
>
>
